question: Question 1 Two identical nMOS transistors [latex]M_{1}[/latex]  and [latex]M_{2}[/latex]  are connected as shown below. The circuit is used as an amplifier with the input connected between G and S terminals and the output taken between D and S terminals. [latex]V_{bias}[/latex]  and [latex]V_{D}[/latex]  are so adjusted that both transistors are in saturation. The transconductance of this combination is defined as [latex]g_{m}=\frac{\partial i_{D}}{\partial V_{GS}}[/latex]  while the output resistance is [latex]r_{0}=\frac{\partial V_{GS}}{\partial i_{D}}[/latex] , where [latex]i_{D}[/latex] is the current flowing into the drain of  [latex]M_{2}[/latex]. Let [latex]g_{m1}[/latex] , [latex]g_{m2}[/latex] be the transconductances and [latex]r_{01}[/latex]  , [latex]r_{02}[/latex]  be the output resistances of transistors [latex]M_{1}[/latex]  and [latex]M_{2}[/latex] , respectively. Which of the following statements about estimates for [latex]g_{m}[/latex]  and [latex]r_{0}[/latex]  is correct?
solution: [latex]g_{m}=\frac{\Delta I_{D}}{\Delta V_{\text {in }}}=\frac{i_{D}}{v_{g s}}=\frac{i_{D 1}}{v_{g s}}=g_{m 1}[/latex] To calculate [latex]r_{o}[/latex] : [latex] \begin{aligned} v_{\pi 2} &=-I_{x} r_{01} \\ I_{x} &=g_{m 2} v_{\pi 2}+\frac{\left(V_{x}-I_{x} r_{01}\right)}{r_{02}} \\ I_{x} &=-g_{m 2} r_{01} I_{x}+\frac{V_{x}}{r_{02}}-I_{x} \frac{r_{01}}{r_{02}} \\ V_{x} &=r_{02}\left[1+r_{01} g_{m 2}+\frac{r_{01}}{r_{02}}\right] I_{x} \\ r_{0} &=\frac{V_{x}}{I_{x}}=r_{01}+r_{02}+r_{01} r_{02} g_{m 2} \\ & \approx r_{01} r_{02} g_{m 2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

options.C: [latex]g_{m}\approx g_{m1} \; and \; r_{0}\approx r_{01} \cdot g_{m2}\cdot r_{02}.[/latex]

question:
Question 2 In the circuit shown below, the op-amp is ideal and Zener voltage of the diode is 2.5 volts.
At the input, unit step voltage is applied, i.e. [latex]  v_{IN}(t)= u(t) [/latex] volts. Also, at t= 0, the
voltage across each of the capacitors is zero. The time t, in milliseconds, at which the output voltage [latex] v_{OUT} [/latex] crosses -10 V is
solution: [latex]\text{For} \quad t \gt 0,[/latex] [latex]I=\frac{1 V}{1 \mathrm{k} \Omega}=1 \mathrm{mA}[/latex] Till [latex]t=2.5 \mathrm{msec}[/latex], both [latex]V_{1}[/latex] and [latex]V_{2}[/latex] will increase and after [latex]t=2.5 \mathrm{msec}[/latex], [latex]V_{2}=2.5 \mathrm{V}[/latex] and [latex]V_{1}[/latex] increases with time. [latex] \begin{aligned} \text { when } v_{\text {out }}(t) &=-10 \mathrm{V} \\ & V_{1}=7.5 \mathrm{V}\\ \text{So,}\\ \frac{1}{1 \mu F} \int_{0}^{t}(1 \mathrm{m} \mathrm{A}) d t &=7.5 \mathrm{V} \\ 10^{3} t &=7.5 \\ t &=7.5 \mathrm{msec} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 3 A good transimpedance amplifier has
solution:
A good transimpedance amplifier should have low
input impedance and low output impedance

options.A: low input impedance and high output impedance.
options.B: high input impedance and high output impedance.
options.C: high input impedance and low output impedance.
options.D: low input impedance and low output impedance.

question:
Question 4 Let the input be u and the output be y of a system, and the other parameters are real
constants. Identify which among the following systems is not a linear system:
solution: [latex]y=a u+b, b \neq 0 [/latex] is a non-linear system.

options.A: [latex]\frac{d^{3}y}{dt^{3}} + a_{1} \frac{d^{2}y}{dt^{2}} + a_{2}\frac{dy}{dt} + a_{3}y =[/latex] [latex]b_{3}u+b_{2}\frac{du}{dt}+b_{1}\frac{d^{2}u}{dt^{2}}[/latex] (with initial rest conditions)

question:
Question 5 The Nyquist stability criterion and the Routh criterion both are powerful analysis tools for
determining the stability of feedback controllers. Identify which of the following statements
is FALSE:

options.A: Both the criteria provide information relative to the stable gain range of the system.
options.B:
The general shape of the Nyquist plot is readily obtained from the Bode magnitude plot
for all minimum-phase systems.
options.C:
The Routh criterion is not applicable in the condition of transport lag, which can be
readily handled by the Nyquist criterion.
options.D:
The closed-loop frequency response for a unity feedback system cannot be obtained
from the Nyquist plot.

question: Question 6 Consider p(s) = [latex]s^{3}+a_{2}s^{2}+a_{1}s+a_{0}[/latex] with all real coefficients. It is known that its derivative  [latex]{p}'(s)[/latex] has no real roots. The number of real roots of  [latex]{p}(s)[/latex] is
solution:
If  p(s) has "r" real roots, then  [latex]p^{\prime}(s)[/latex]  will have atleast [latex]
 "r-1^{\prime \prime}[/latex]  real roots.

question:
Question 7 In a p-n junction diode at equilibrium, which one of the following statements is
NOT TRUE?
solution: [latex]\longrightarrow[/latex] Hole diffusion [latex] \longleftarrow[/latex] Electron diffusion [latex] \longleftarrow[/latex] Hole drift [latex] \longrightarrow[/latex] Electron drift [latex] \longrightarrow[/latex] Hole diffusion current [latex] \longrightarrow[/latex] Electron diffusion current [latex] \longleftarrow[/latex] Hole drift current [latex] \longleftarrow[/latex] Electron drift current

options.A: The hole and electron diffusion current components are in the same direction.
options.B: The hole and electron drift current components are in the same direction.
options.C: On an average, holes and electrons drift in opposite direction.
options.D: On an average, electrons drift and diffuse in the same direction.

question: Question 8 The logic function f(X,Y) realized by the given circuit is
solution: From pull-down network, [latex] \begin{aligned} \overline{f(X, Y)}&=\bar{X} \bar{Y}+X Y=X \odot Y \\ f(X, Y)&=\overline{X \odot Y}=X \oplus Y \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 9 A function F(A,B,C) defined by three Boolean variables A, B and C when expressed as sum
of products is given by [latex]F=\bar{A}\cdot \bar{B} \cdot \bar{C} + \bar{A}\cdot B \cdot \bar{C} + A\cdot \bar{B} \cdot \bar{C}[/latex] where,[latex]\bar{A},\bar{B} \;and \; \bar{C} [/latex] are complements of the respective variable. The product of sums (POS) form of the function F is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} F(A, B, C, D) &=\bar{A} \bar{B} \bar{C}+\bar{A} B \bar{C}+A \bar{B} \bar{C} \\ &=\Sigma m(0,2,4)=\Pi M(1,3,5,6,7) \\ =&(A+B+\bar{C})(A+\bar{B}+\bar{C})(\bar{A}+B+\bar{C}) \\ &(\bar{A}+\bar{B}+C)(\bar{A}+\bar{B}+\bar{C}) & \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 10 The points P, Q, and R shown on the Smith chart (normalized impedance chart) in the
following figure represent:
solution: For Short circuit, [latex] r=x=0 \quad \Rightarrow \text { Point } " P^{\prime \prime}[/latex] For Open circuit, [latex] r=x=\infty \quad \Rightarrow \text { Point }^{\prime \prime} R^{\prime \prime}[/latex] For Matched load, [latex] r=1 \text { and } x=0 \Rightarrow \text { Point " } Q^{\prime \prime}[/latex] P: Short Circuit, Q: Matched Load R: Open circuit

options.A: P: Open Circuit, Q: Short Circuit, R: Matched Load
options.B: P: Open Circuit, Q: Matched Load, R: Short Circuit
options.C: P: Short Circuit, Q: Matched Load, R: Open Circuit
options.D: P: Short Circuit, Q: Open Circuit, R: Matched Load

question: Question 11 Let M be a real 4[latex]\times[/latex]4 matrix. Consider the following statements: S1: M has 4 linearly independent eigenvectors. S2: M has 4 distinct eigenvalues. S3: M is non-singular (invertible). Which one among the following is TRUE?
solution:
Eigen vectors corresponding to distinct eigen 
values are linearly independent. Hence, "S2 implies S1 ".

question: Question 12 Let [latex]f(x,y)=\frac{ax^{2}+by^{2}}{xy}[/latex] ,where a and b are constants. If [latex]\frac{\partial f}{\partial x} = \frac{\partial f}{\partial y}[/latex]  at x=1 and y=2 , then the relation between  a and b is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} f(x, y) &=\frac{a x^{2}+b y^{2}}{x y}=a\left(\frac{x}{y}\right)+b\left(\frac{y}{x}\right) \\\left.\frac{\partial f}{\partial x}\right|_{(1,2)} &=\left.\left[\frac{a}{y}-\frac{b y}{x^{2}}\right]\right|_{(12)}-\frac{a}{2}-2 b \\\left.\frac{\partial f}{\partial y}\right|_{(1,2)} &=\left.\left[-\frac{a x}{y^{2}}+\frac{b}{x}\right]\right|_{(1,2)}=-\frac{a}{4}+b \\ \frac{\partial f}{\partial x} &=\frac{\partial f}{\partial y} \\ \text{So,}\quad \frac{a}{2}-2 b &=-\frac{a}{4}+b \\ \frac{3 a}{4}&=3 b \\ a&=4 b \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 13 A discrete-time all-pass system has two of its poles at 0.25[latex]\angle 0^{\circ}[/latex]  and 2[latex]\angle 30^{\circ}[/latex]. Which one of the following statements about the system is TRUE?
solution:
The AOC should include unit circle to make the 
system stable. From the given pole pattern it is 
clear that, to make the system stable, the ROC 
should be finite circular strip or finite annular strip 
and hence the impulse response of the system 
should be also two-sided.

options.A: It has two more poles at 0.5[latex]\angle 0^{\circ}[/latex]  and 4[latex]\angle 0^{\circ}[/latex]  .
options.B: It is stable only when the impulse response is two-sided.
options.C: It has constant phase response over all frequencies.
options.D: It has constant phase response over the entire z-plane.

question:
Question 14 Let x(t) be a periodic function with period T = 10. The Fourier series coefficients for this
series are denoted by [latex] a_{k} [/latex], that is [latex]x(t)=\sum_{k=-\infty }^{\infty }a_{k}e^{jk\frac{2\pi }{T}t}[/latex] The same function x(t) can also be considered function with period [latex]{T=40}'[/latex]. Let [latex]b_{k}[/latex] be the fourier series cofficients when period is taken as [latex]{T}'[/latex]. If  [latex]\sum_{k=-\infty}^{\infty}|a_{k}|=16[/latex] ,then [latex]\sum_{k=-\infty}^{\infty}|a_{k}| [/latex] is equal to
solution: Change in only time period or frequency does not change in the value of Fourier series coefficients So, [latex] \begin{aligned} b_{k} &=a_{k} \\ \sum_{k=-\infty}^{\infty}\left|b_{k}\right| &=\sum_{k=-\infty}^{\infty}\left|a_{k}\right|=16 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 15 Consider the following amplitude modulated signal: [latex]s(t)=cos(2000\pi t)+4cos(2400\pi t)+cos(2800\pi t).[/latex] The ratio (accurate to three decimal places) of the power of the message signal to the power of the carrier signal is __________.
solution: The power of the carrier signal is, [latex] P_{c}=\frac{(4)^{2}}{2}=8 \mathrm{W}[/latex] The power of message signal can be taken as the power carried by the sidebands. So, the power of the message signal is, [latex] P_{m}=2\left[\frac{(1)^{2}}{2}\right]=1 \mathrm{W}[/latex] Required ratio, [latex] \frac{P_{m}}{P_{c}}=\frac{1}{8}=0.125[/latex]

question:
Question 16 Consider a binary channel code in which each codeword has a fixed length of 5 bits. The
Hamming distance between any pair of distinct codewords in this code is at least 2. The
maximum number of codewords such a code can contain is _________.
solution: According to the Plotkin bound. [latex] \begin{aligned} d_{\min } &\leq \frac{n 2^{k-1}}{2^{k}-1}\\ n&= \text{ Length of each code word }\\ k&= \text{ Length of each message word} \\ \text{Given that.}\\ d_{\min }&=2 \text { and } n=5\\ \text{So, } \frac{2^{k}}{2\left(2^{k}-1\right)} &\geq \frac{2}{5} \\ \frac{2^{k}}{2^{k}-1} &\geq \frac{4}{5} \end{aligned}[/latex] For any value of k, the above bound will be  satisfied. But as [latex]n > k[/latex] and n is fixed at 5. The maximum value of k that can be selected is 4. So, the maximum number of codewords possible is [latex]2_{4} = 16[/latex].

question:
Question 17 A binary source generates symbols [latex] X \in \{-1,1\} [/latex]which are transmitted over a noisy channel. The probability of transmitting X= 1 is 0.5. Input to the threshold detector is R= X + N.
The probability density function [latex]f_{N}(n)[/latex] of the noise N is shown below. If the detection threshold is zero, then the probability of error (correct to two decimal
places) is __________.
solution: Let [latex]s_{0}[/latex] and [latex]s_{1}[/latex] be the transmitted symbols representing the transmitted value {-1 , 1} respectively and let [latex]r_{0}[/latex] and [latex]r_{1}[/latex] be the received symbols. Probability of error, [latex] \begin{aligned} P_{e} &=P\left(s_{1}\right) P\left(r_{0} \mid s_{1}\right)+P\left(s_{0}\right) P\left(r_{1} \mid s_{0}\right) \\ P\left(r_{0} \mid s_{1}\right) &=P\left(r_{1} \mid s_{0}\right)=\frac{1}{2} \times 1 \times \frac{1}{4}=\frac{1}{8}\\ \text{Given that,}\\ P\left(s_{0}\right)&=P\left(s_{1}\right)=\frac{1}{2}\\ \text{So}\quad P_{e}&=\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{1}{8}+\frac{1}{8}\right)=\frac{1}{8}=0.125 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 18 A p-n step junction diode with a contact potential of 0.65V has a depletion width of 1[latex]\mu[/latex]m
at equilibrium. The forward voltage (in volts, correct to two decimal places) at which this
width reduces to 0.6 [latex]\mu[/latex]m is _______.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} W_{\mathrm{dep}} &=\sqrt{\frac{2 \varepsilon}{q}\left(\frac{1}{N_{A}}+\frac{1}{N_{D}}\right)\left(V_{b i}-V_{A K}\right)} \\ \frac{\sqrt{\left(0.65-V_{A K}\right)}}{\sqrt{0.65}} &=\frac{0.6 \mu \mathrm{m}}{1 \mu \mathrm{m}}=0.6 \\ 1-\frac{V_{A K}}{0.65} &=0.36 \\ V_{A K} &=0.65(1-0.36) \\ &=0.65 \times 0.64=0.416 \mathrm{V} \simeq 0.42 \mathrm{V} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 19 A traffic signal cycles from GREEN to YELLOW, YELLOW to RED and RED to GREEN.
In each cycle, GREEN is turned on for 70 seconds, YELLOW is turned on for
5 seconds and the RED is turned on for 75 seconds. This traffic light has to be implemented
using a finite state machine (FSM). The only input to this FSM is a clock of 5 second period.
The minimum number of flip-flops required to implement this FSM is _______.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{GREEN }&\rightarrow 70 \text{seconds}\\ \text { YELLOW } & \rightarrow 5 \text { seconds } \\ \text { RED } &\rightarrow 75 \text { seconds }\\ \text{Clock period }&\rightarrow 5 \text{seconds }\\ \end{aligned}[/latex] Total number of unique states required [latex] =\frac{70+5+75}{5}=30[/latex] Minimum number of flip-flops required is, [latex] n=\left\lceil\log _{2}(30)\right\rceil=\lceil 4.91\rceil=5[/latex]

question:
Question 20 There are two photolithography systems: one with light source of wavelength [latex]\lambda _{1}[/latex] = 156 nm
(System 1) and another with light source of wavelength [latex]\lambda _{2}[/latex] = 325 nm (System 2). Both
photolithography systems are otherwise identical. If the minimum feature sizes that can be
realized using System1 and System2 are [latex] L_{min1} \; and \; L_{min2} [/latex] respectively, the ratio [latex] L_{min1}/L_{min2} [/latex](correct to two decimal places) is__________.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} L_{min}&\propto \lambda \\ \frac{L_{min1}}{L_{min2}}&=\frac{\lambda _1}{\lambda _2} \\ &= \frac{156nm}{325nm}=0.48 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 21 A lossy transmission line has resistance per unit length R = 0.05 [latex]\Omega [/latex] /m. The line is
distortionless and has characteristic impedance of 50 [latex]\Omega [/latex]. The attenuation constant (in Np/m, correct to three decimal places) of the line is _______.
solution: For a distortionless transmission line, [latex] \frac{L}{R}=\frac{C}{G}[/latex] Propagation constant, [latex] \begin{aligned} \gamma &=\alpha+j \beta=\sqrt{(R+j \omega L)(G+j \omega C)} \\ &=\sqrt{R G}\left(1+j \omega \frac{L}{R}\right) \end{aligned}[/latex] Attenuation constant, [latex] \alpha=\sqrt{R G}[/latex] Characteristic impedance, [latex] \begin{aligned} Z_{0} &=\sqrt{\frac{(R+j \omega L)}{(G+j \omega C)}}=\sqrt{\frac{R}{G}} \\ \sqrt{G} &=\frac{\sqrt{R}}{Z_{0}} \\ \text{So,}\quad\alpha &=\sqrt{R} \cdot \frac{\sqrt{R}}{Z_{0}}=\frac{R}{Z_{0}} \\ &=\frac{0.05}{50}=\frac{0.01}{10}=0.001 \mathrm{Np} / \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 22 Consider matrix [latex]A=\begin{bmatrix} k & 2k\\ k^{2}-k & k^{2} \end{bmatrix}[/latex]  and vector [latex]x=\begin{bmatrix} x_{1}\\ x_{2} \end{bmatrix}[/latex]. The number of distinct real values of k for which the equation  Ax=0 has infinitely many solutions is _______.
solution:
A X=0  has infinitely many solutions [latex]
\begin{aligned} 
\text{So, }\quad|A|=0 ;&\left|\begin{array}{cc}k & 2 k \\ k^{2}-k k^{2}\end{array}\right|=0 \\
k^{3}-2 k^{3}+2 k^{2} &=0 ; \quad k^{2}(2-k)=0 \\ 
k &=0,2 
\end{aligned} [/latex] [latex]
 \Rightarrow [/latex] "two" distinct values of k

question: Question 23 Let [latex] X_{1} , X_{2} , X_{3} \; and \;  X_{4} [/latex] be independent normal random variables with zero mean and unit variance. The probability that [latex] X_{4} [/latex]  is the smallest among the four is _______.
solution: [latex]P\left(X_{4} \text { is smallest }\right)=\frac{3 !}{4 !}=\frac{1}{4}=0.25[/latex]

question: Question 24 Taylor series expansion of [latex]f(x)=\int_{0}^{x} e^{-({\frac{t^{2}}{2}})}dt[/latex] at around x=0 has the form [latex]f(x)=a_{0}+a_{1}x+a_{2}x^{2}+...   [/latex]. The coefficient [latex]a_{2}[/latex] (correct to two decimal places) is equal to _______.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} f(x) &=\int_{0}^{x} e^{-t^{2} / 2} d t \\ f^{\prime}(x) &=e^{-x^{2} / 2} \text { and } f^{\prime \prime}(x)=e^{-x^{2} / 2}(-x) \\ f^{\prime \prime}(0) &=0 \\ a_{2} &=\frac{f^{\prime \prime}(0)}{2 !}=0 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 25 The ABCD matrix for a two-port network is defined by: [latex]\begin{bmatrix} V_{1}\\ I_{1} \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} A & B\\ C & D \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} V_{2}\\ - l_{2} \end{bmatrix}[/latex] The parameter B for the given two-port network (in ohms, correct to two decimal places)
is _______.
solution: [latex]B=-\left.\frac{V_{1}}{I_{2}}\right|_{V_{2}=0}[/latex] When [latex]V_{2}=0[/latex] (i.e., when port-2 is short circuited) [latex] \begin{aligned} I_{1}&=\frac{V_{1}}{2 \Omega+(5 \Omega \| 2 \Omega)}=\frac{7 V_{1}}{24 \Omega}\\ I_{2}&=-I_{1} \times \frac{5 \Omega}{5 \Omega+2 \Omega}=\frac{-5 V_{1}}{24 \Omega}\\ \text { So, } \quad B&=-\frac{V_{1}}{I_{2}}=\frac{24}{5} \Omega=4.80 \Omega \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 26 The circuit shown in the figure is used to provide regulated voltage (5 V) across the 1k[latex]\Omega[/latex]
resistor. Assume that the Zener diode has a constant reverse breakdown voltage for a current
range, starting from a minimum required Zener current, [latex] I_{Z_{min}} = 2 mA [/latex] to its maximum
allowable current. The input voltage [latex] V_{I} [/latex] may vary by 5% from its nominal value of 6 V. The
resistance of the diode in the breakdown region is negligible. The value of R and the minimum required power dissipation rating of the diode,
respectively, are
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} V_{I} &=6 \mathrm{V} \pm 5 \%=6 \mathrm{V} \pm 0.3 \mathrm{V} \\ &=5.7 \mathrm{V} \text { to } 6.3 \mathrm{V}\\ I_{L} &=\frac{5 \mathrm{V}}{1 \mathrm{k} \Omega}=5 \mathrm{m} \mathrm{A} \\ I_{\mathrm{s}(\mathrm{min})} &=I_{L}+I_{Z_{\mathrm{Tmin}}}=5 \mathrm{m} \mathrm{A}+2 \mathrm{m} \mathrm{A} \\ &=7 \mathrm{m} \mathrm{A} \\ I_{s} &=\frac{V_{I}-V_{z}}{R} \\ I_{\mathrm{s}(\min )} &=\frac{V_{I(\min )}-V_{z}}{R}=7 \mathrm{m} \mathrm{A} \\ \text{So,}\quad R &=\frac{5.7-5}{7} \mathrm{k} \Omega=\frac{700}{7} \Omega=100 \Omega\\ \text{When},\quad R=100 \Omega \\ I_{s(\max )} &=\frac{6.3-5}{100} \mathrm{A}=13 \mathrm{mA} \\ I_{z(\max )} &=I_{s(\max )}-I_{L}=13 \mathrm{mA}-5 \mathrm{mA} \\ &=8 \mathrm{mA} \\ P_{z(\min )} &=V_{z} I_{z(\max )}=(5 \times 8) \mathrm{mW}=40 \mathrm{mW} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 27 Let [latex] c(t)=A_{c} cos(2\pi f_{c}t) \; and  \; m(t)=cos(2\pi f_{m}t) [/latex]. It is given that [latex] f_{c}>>5f_{m} [/latex]. The signal [latex] c(t) +m(t) [/latex]  is applied to the input of a non-linear device, whose output [latex] v_{o}(t) [/latex] is related to the input [latex] v_{i}(t)+bv_{i}(t) [/latex],where a and b  are positive constants. The output of the non-linear device is passed through an ideal band-pass filter with center frequency [latex] f_{c} [/latex] and bandwidth [latex] 3f_{m}[/latex] ,to produce an amplitude modulated (AM) wave. If it is desired to have the sideband power of the AM wave to be half of the carrier power, then [latex]a/b[/latex] is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} v_{f t}^{(t)} &=A_{c} \cos \left(2 \pi f_{c} t\right)+\cos \left(2 \pi t_{m} t\right) \\ v_{d}(t) &=a v_{i}(t)+b v_{i}^{2}(t) \\ =&\left[a A_{c} \cos \left(2 \pi t_{c} t\right)+a \cos \left(2 \pi f_{m} t\right)\right] \\ \quad &+b\left[\begin{array}{c}A_{c}^{2} \cos ^{2}\left(2 \pi f_{c} t\right)+\cos ^{2}\left(2 \pi f_{m} t\right) \\ +2 A_{c} \cos \left(2 \pi f_{c} t\right) \cos \left(2 \pi t_{m} t\right)\end{array}\right] \end{aligned} [/latex] After passing through the given BPF, [latex] y(t)=a A_{c} \cos 2 \pi f_{c} t+2 b A_{c} \cos \left(2 \pi f_{c} t\right) \cos \left(2 \pi f_{m} t\right) [/latex] [latex] =a A_{c}\left[1+\frac{2 b}{a} \cos \left(2 \pi f_{m} t\right)\right] \cos \left(2 \pi f_{c} t\right) [/latex] Modulation index, [latex] \begin{aligned} \mu &=\begin{array}{l}2 b \\ a\end{array} \\ P_{S B} &=\frac{\mu^{2}}{2} P_{C}=\frac{1}{2} P_{C} \\ \mu^{2} &=1 \Rightarrow \mu=1 \\ \frac{2 b}{a} &=1 \\ \frac{a}{b} &=2 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 28 Consider a white Gaussian noise process N(t) with two-sided power spectral density [latex] S_{N}(f)=0.5 W/Hz [/latex] as input to a filter with impulse response [latex]0.5e^{\frac{-t^{2}}{2}}[/latex] (where t is in seconds) resulting in output Y(t). The power in Y(t) in watts is
solution: PSD of noise input. [latex] S_{(t)}^{S}(f)=0.50 \mathrm{W} / \mathrm{Hz} [/latex] Power of y(t) [latex] \begin{aligned} P_{y} &=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} S_{N}(f)|H(f)|^{2} d f \\ &=0.50 \int_{-\infty}^{\infty}|H(f)|^{2} d f \\ &=0.50 \int_{-\infty}^{\infty}|h(t)|^{2} d t\\ \text{Given that,}\\ h(t)&=\frac{1}{2} e^{-t^{2} / 2}\\ \text{So}\quad P_{y} &=\frac{1}{2} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty}\left(\frac{1}{2} e^{-t^{2} / 2}\right)^{2} d t \\ &=\frac{1}{8} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{-t^{2}} d t \\ &=\frac{\sqrt{\pi}}{8}=0.2215 \mathrm{W} \simeq 0.22 \mathrm{W} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 29 The state equation and the output equation of a control system are given below: [latex]\dot{x}=\begin{bmatrix} -4 & -1.5\\ 4 & 0 \end{bmatrix}x+\begin{bmatrix} 2\\ 0\end{bmatrix}u,[/latex] [latex]y=\begin{bmatrix} 1.5 & 0.625 \end{bmatrix}x.[/latex] The transfer function representation of the system is
solution: Transfer function [latex]\begin{aligned} T(s) &=\frac{Y(s)}{U(s)}=\mathrm{C}(s I-A]^{-1} \mathrm{B} \\ A &=\left[\begin{array}{cc} -4 & -1.5 \\ 4 & 0 \end{array}\right] \\ B &=\left[\begin{array}{c} 2 \\ 0 \end{array}\right] \\ C&=[1.5\quad0.625]\\ {[s I-A]} & =\left[\begin{array}{cc}s+4 & 1.5 \\-4 & s\end{array}\right] \\ {[s I-A]^{-1}} & =\frac{1}{\left(s^{2}+4 s+6\right)}\left[\begin{array}{cc}s & -1.5 \\4 & s+4 \end{array}\right] \\ {[s I-A]^{-1} B} & =\frac{1}{s^{2}+4 s+6}\left[\begin{array}{c}2 s \\8 \end{array}\right] & \\ C[s I-A]^{-1} B & =\frac{1}{s^{2}+4 s+6}[1.5 \quad 0.625]\left[\begin{array}{c}2 s \\ 8\end{array}\right] \\ T(s) & =\frac{3 s+5}{s^{2}+4 s+6} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 30 Red (R), Green (G) and Blue (B) Light Emitting Diodes (LEDs) were fabricated using p-n
junctions of three different inorganic semiconductors having different band-gaps. The builtin
voltages of red, green and blue diodes are [latex] V_{R}, V_{G} \; and \; V_{B} [/latex], respectively. Assume donor and acceptor doping to be the same [latex] (N_{A} \; and \; N_{D} [/latex], respectively) in the p and n sides of all the three diodes. Which one of the following relationships about the built-in voltages is TRUE?
solution: [latex]\lambda_{R} \gt \lambda_{G} \gt \lambda_{B}[/latex] Energy gap, [latex] E_{g} \propto \frac{1}{\lambda} [/latex] So, [latex]E_{g R} \lt E_{g G}  \lt  E_{g B}[/latex] Materials with high energy gap will have high built-in voltages, when doping concentrations are same. So, [latex]V_{R} \lt V_{G}  \lt V_{B}[/latex]

question: Question 31 A four-variable Boolean function is realized using 4x1 multiplexers as shown in the figure. The minimized expression for F(U,V,W, X) is
solution: Output of the first multiplexer can be expressed as, [latex] F_{1}=\bar{U} V+U \bar{V}[/latex] Output of the second multiplexer can be expressed as, [latex] \begin{aligned} F &=\bar{W} \bar{X} F_{1}+\bar{W} X F_{1}=\bar{W} F_{1} \\ &=(\bar{U} V+U \bar{V}) \bar{W} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 32 A 2[latex]\times[/latex]  2 ROM array is built with the help of diodes as shown in the circuit below. Here W0
and W1 are signals that select the word lines and B0 and B1 are signals that are output of the
sense amps based on the stored data corresponding to the bit lines during the read operation. During the read operation, the selected word line goes high and the other word line is in a
high impedance state. As per the implementation shown in the circuit diagram above, what are the bits corresponding to [latex] D_{ij} [/latex] (where i = 0 or 1 and j = 0 or 1)  stored in the ROM?
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} \text { When, } W_{0}=V_{D O}, B_{0}=V_{D D} \text { ; otherwise } B_{0}=0 \\ \text { When } W_{1}=V_{D O} B_{1}=V_{D D} \text { ; otherwise } B_{1}=0 \\ \text { So, } B_{0}=W_{0} \text { and } B_{1}=W_{1} \\ \text { Hence } \begin{array}{c|cc} &B_{0}&B_{1}\\ \hline W_{0}&1&0\\ W_{1}&0&1 \end{array}\\ \end{array}[/latex]

question:
Question 33 The distance (in meters) a wave has to propagate in a medium having a skin depth of 0.1 m
so that the amplitude of the wave attenuates by 20 dB, is
solution: Attenuation constant, [latex] \begin{aligned} \alpha &=\frac{1}{\text { skin depth }}=10 \mathrm{Np} / \mathrm{m} \\ \text { 20log }_{10}\left(\frac{E_{0}}{E_{x}}\right) &=20 \mathrm{dB} \\ \frac{E_{o}}{E_{x}} &=10 \Rightarrow E_{x}=\frac{E_{0}}{10} \\ E_{x} &=E_{0} e^{-\alpha x}=E_{0} e^{-10 x}=\frac{E_{0}}{10} \\ e^{-10 x} &=\frac{1}{10} \\ x &=\frac{1}{10} \ln (10)=0.23 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 34 A curve passes through the point (x =1, y = 0) and satisfies the differential equation [latex]\frac{dy}{dx}=\frac{x^{2}+y^{2}}{2y} + \frac{y}{x}[/latex]. The equation that describes the curve is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{d y}{d x} &=\frac{x^{2}}{2 y}+\frac{y}{2}+\frac{y}{x} \\ \text { Put. } \frac{y}{x}=t \\ \frac{d y}{d x}&=t+x \frac{d t}{d x} \\ t+x \frac{d t}{d x} &=\frac{x}{2 t}+\frac{t x}{2}+t \\ x \frac{d t}{d x} &=x\left(\frac{1}{2 t}+\frac{t}{2}\right) \\ x \frac{d t}{d x} &=x\left(\frac{1+t^{2}}{2 t}\right) \\ \frac{2 t}{1+t^{2}} d t &=\int d x+C \\ \ln \left(1+t^{2}\right) &=x+c \\ t &=\frac{y}{x}\\ \text{So, }\ln \left(1+\frac{y^{2}}{x^{2}}\right)&=x+C \\ \text{At }x=1, y=0 \\ \ln \left(1+\frac{0}{1}\right) &=\ln (1)=0=1+C \\ C &=-1 \\ \text{So,} \ln \left(1+\frac{y^{2}}{x^{2}}\right)&=x-1 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 35 For the circuit given in the figure, the voltage [latex]V_{C}[/latex] (in volts) across the capacitor is
solution: [latex]\frac{1}{\omega C}=\frac{1}{5 \times 10^{-6}}=200 \mathrm{k} \Omega[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} V_{C} &=\frac{5 \angle 0^{\circ}}{200-j 200} \times(-j 200) \vee \\ &=\frac{5 \angle 0^{\circ} \times 1 \angle-90^{\circ}}{\sqrt{2} \angle-45^{\circ}} \mathrm{V} \\ &=\frac{5}{\sqrt{2}} \angle-45^{\circ} \mathrm{V}=2.5 \sqrt{2} \sin \left(5 t-\frac{\pi}{4}\right) \mathrm{V} \\ &=2.5 \sqrt{2} \sin (5 t-0.25 \pi) \mathrm{V} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 36 For the circuit given in the figure, the magnitude of the loop current (in amperes, correct to
three decimal places) 0.5 second after closing the switch is _______.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Loop current, } i(t)&=\frac{1}{1+1}\left(1-e^{-t / \tau}\right) \mathrm{A} ; t \gt 0 \\ \tau&=\frac{L}{R_{e q}}=\frac{1}{1+1}=\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{sec} \\ i(t)&=\frac{1}{2}\left(1-e^{-2 t}\right) \mathrm{A} ; t \gt 0\\ \text{At }t=0.5 \mathrm{sec} \\ i(t)&=\frac{1}{2}\left(1-e^{-1}\right) \mathrm{A}=0.316 \mathrm{A} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 37 A DC current of 26[latex]\mu A[/latex] flows through the circuit shown. The diode in the circuit is forward
biased and it has an ideality factor of one. At the quiescent point, the diode has a junction
capacitance of 0.5 nF . Its neutral region resistances can be neglected. Assume that the room
temperature thermal equivalent voltage is 26 mV. For [latex] \omega =2 \times 10^{6} \; rad/s [/latex], the amplitude of the small-signal component of diode current (in [latex]\mu A[/latex],
correct to one decimal place) is _______.
solution: The small-signal equivalent model of the given circuit can be drawn as shown below. [latex] \begin{aligned} \text{Given that, }\omega&=2 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{sec} \\ C_{j} &=0.5 \mathrm{nF} \\ I_{\mathrm{DC}} &=26 \mu \mathrm{A} \\ V_{T} &=26 \mathrm{mV} \\ \eta &=1\\ \mathrm{So} \quad r_{d} &=\frac{\eta V_{T}}{I_{\mathrm{DC}}}=\frac{26 \mathrm{mV}}{26 \mu \mathrm{A}}=1 \mathrm{k} \Omega \\ \frac{1}{\omega C_{j}} &=\frac{1}{2 \times 10^{6} \times 0.5 \times 10^{-9}} \Omega=1 \mathrm{k} \Omega \end{aligned}[/latex] So, total impedance of the circuit will be, [latex] \begin{aligned} Z &=\left(r_{d} \| \frac{1}{j \omega C_{j}}\right)+100 \Omega \\\left(r_{d} \| \frac{1}{j \omega C_{j}}\right) &=\frac{(1000)(-j 1000)}{1000-j 1000} \Omega \\ &=\frac{-j(1+j)}{2} \mathrm{k} \Omega \\ &=\frac{1}{2}(1-j) \mathrm{k} \Omega=(500-j 500) \Omega \\ \therefore \quad Z &=600-j 500 \Omega \\|Z| &=100 \sqrt{36+25}=100 \sqrt{61} \Omega \\ I_{m} &=\frac{V_{m}}{|Z|} \\ &=\frac{5 \mathrm{mV}}{100 \sqrt{61} \Omega}=\frac{50}{\sqrt{61}} \mu \mathrm{A}=6.40 \mu \mathrm{A} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 38 An op-amp based circuit is implemented as shown below. In the above circuit, assume the op-amp to be ideal. The voltage (in volts, correct to one decimal place) at node A, connected to the negative input of the op-amp as indicated in the figure is _________.
solution: Applying the concept of virtual ground, we get [latex] \begin{aligned} V_{o}&=-\frac{R_{2}}{R_{1}} \cdot V_{i n}\\ [\therefore & \text{ non-inverting amplifiel}]\\ \therefore \quad V_{o}&=-\frac{31 \mathrm{k} \Omega}{1 \mathrm{k} \Omega} \times 1 \mathrm{V}\\ V_{0}&=-31 \mathrm{V} \lt -15 \mathrm{V} \end{aligned}[/latex] which is not possible Hence, the output voltage of the op-amp is equal to [latex] -15 \mathrm{V}[/latex] Now applying KCL of node 'A', we get. [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{V_{A}-(-15)}{31 \mathrm{k} \Omega}+\frac{V_{A}-1}{1 \mathrm{k} \Omega} &=0 \\ \frac{V_{A}}{31 \mathrm{k} \Omega}+\frac{V_{A}}{1 \mathrm{k} \Omega} &=\frac{-15}{31 \mathrm{k} \Omega}+\frac{1}{1 \mathrm{k} \Omega} \\ V_{A}\left[\frac{1}{31}+\frac{1}{1}\right] &=-\frac{15}{31}+1 \\ V_{A} &=0.5 \mathrm{V} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 39 The input 4sinc(2t) is fed to a Hilbert transformer to obtain y(t), as shown in the figure
below: Here 
[latex]sinc(x)=\frac{sin(\pi x)}{\pi x}[/latex]. The value (accurate to two decimal places) of [latex]\int_{-\infty }^{\infty } |y(t)|^{2}dt[/latex] is _______.
solution: Hilbert transform does not alter the amplitude spectrum of the signal. [latex] \begin{aligned} \text{So, }\quad \int_{-\infty}^{\infty}|y(t)|^{2} d t&=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}|x(t)|^{2} d t=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}|X(f)|^{2} d f \\ x(t)&=4 \sin \mathrm{c}(2 t) \\ \text{sinc}(t) &\stackrel{CTFT}{\longleftrightarrow} \text{rect}(f) \\ 4 \text{sinc}(2 t) &\stackrel{CTFT}{\longleftrightarrow}+\frac{4}{2} \text{rect}\left(\frac{f}{2}\right)=2 \text{rect}\left(\frac{f}{2}\right) \end{aligned}\\ \begin{aligned} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty}|X(f)|^{2} d f &=2 \times(2)^{2}=8 \\ \text { So. } \int_{-\infty}^{\infty}|y(t)|^{2} d t &=8 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 40 A random variable X takes values -0.5 and 0.5 with probabilities 1/4 and 3/4, respectively.
The noisy observation of X is Y = X + Z, where Z has uniform probability density over
the interval (-1, 1). X and Z are independent. If the MAP rule based detector outputs [latex]\hat{X}[/latex]  as [latex]\hat{X}=\left\{\begin{matrix} -0.5 \; \; \; Y \lt \alpha \\ 0.5 \; \; \; Y \geq \alpha \end{matrix}\right.[/latex] then the value of [latex]\alpha [/latex] (accurate to two decimal places) is _______.
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{c} P\left(x_{0}\right)=\frac{1}{4} ; P\left(x_{1}\right)=\frac{3}{4} \\ \text { MAP criteria, } f_{Y}\left(y \mid x_{0}\right) P\left(x_{0}\right) \overset{x_{2}}{\underset{x_{1}}{\gtrless}}\left(y \mid x_{1}\right) P\left(x_{1}\right) \end{array}[/latex] [latex]\text{So}\quad \alpha=-0.5[/latex]

question: Question 41 For a unity feedback control system with the forward path transfer function [latex]G(s)=\frac{K}{s(s+2)}[/latex] The peak resonant magnitude [latex]M_{r}[/latex], of the closed-loop frequency response is 2. The corresponding value of the gain K (correct to two decimal places) is _________.
solution: Maximum resonant peak, [latex]\begin{aligned} M_{r} &=\frac{1}{2 \xi \sqrt{1-\xi^{2}}}=2 \\ 2 \xi \sqrt{1-\xi^{2}} &=\frac{1}{2} \\ \xi^{2}\left(1-\xi^{2}\right) &=\frac{1}{16} \\ \xi^{4}-\xi^{2}+\frac{1}{16} &=0 \\ \xi^{2}&=\frac{1}{2} \pm \sqrt{\frac{1-\frac{1}{4}}{4}}=\frac{1}{2} \pm \frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} \\ \text { As } M_{r}=2 \gt 1, \xi& \lt \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \text { and } \xi^{2} \lt \frac{1}{2} \\ \text { So. } \quad\xi^{2}&=\frac{1}{2}-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{4}\\ Given, \quad G(s)&=\frac{K}{s(s+2)}=\frac{\omega_{n}^{2}}{s\left(s+2 \xi \omega_{n}\right)} \\ \text{So} \quad\omega_{n} &=\sqrt{K} \\ 2 \xi \sqrt{K} &=2\\ \sqrt{K} &=\frac{1}{\xi} \\ K &=\frac{1}{\xi^{2}}=\frac{1}{\left(\frac{1}{2}-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{4}\right)} \\ &=\frac{4}{2-\sqrt{3}}=14.928 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 42 The figure below shows the Bode magnitude and phase plots of a stable transfer function [latex]G(s)=\frac{n_{o}}{s^{2}+d_{2}s^{2}+d_{1}+d_{0}}[/latex] Consider the negative unity feedback configuration with gain k in the feedforward path. The closed loop is stable for [latex] k \lt k_{o} [/latex]. The maximum value of [latex]k_{o} [/latex] is ______.
solution: For G(s) [latex] M_{\mathrm{dB}}\left(\omega_{p c}\right)=20 \mathrm{dB} [/latex] When cascaded with k , [latex] \begin{aligned} \mathrm{GM}_{\mathrm{dB}} &=-20 \mathrm{dB}-20 \log _{10}(k) \gt 0 \mathrm{dB} \\ 20+20 \log _{10}(k) & \lt 0 \\ 20 \log _{10}(k) & \lt -20 \\ k & \lt 10^{-1}=0.10\\ \text{So,}\quad k_{0}&=0.10 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 43 In the circuit shown below, the (W/L) value for [latex] M_{2} [/latex] is twice that for [latex] M_{1} [/latex]. The two nMOS
transistors are otherwise identical. The threshold voltage [latex]V_{T}[/latex] for both transistors is 1.0V.
Note that [latex] V_{GS} \; for M_{2} [/latex] must be [latex]\gt[/latex] 1.0 V. The voltage (in volts, accurate to two decimal places) at [latex] V_{x} [/latex] is _______.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Let},\quad K_{n}&=\frac{\mu_{n} C_{o x}}{2}\left(\frac{W}{L}\right)\\ \text{Given that,}\\ \left(\frac{W}{L}\right)_{2} &=2\left(\frac{W}{L}\right)_{1} \\ \text{So,}\quad K_{n 2} &=2 K_{n 1}\\ \text{For }M_{1}, \quad V_{G S 1}-V_{T}&=2-1=1 V \\ \text{For }M_{2}, \quad V_{G S 2}-V_{T}&=2-V_{x}-1=1 \mathrm{V}-V_{x}<1 \mathrm{V} \\ V_{D S 2}&=\left(3.3-V_{x}\right)>\left(V_{G S 2}-V_{T}\right) \end{aligned}[/latex] So, [latex]M_{1}[/latex] will be in linear region and [latex]M_{2}[/latex] will be in saturation region. [latex]\begin{aligned} I_{D_{1}}&=I_{D_{2}} \\ K_{n 1}\left[2\left(V_{G S 1}-V_{T}\right) V_{D S 1}-V_{D S 1}^{2}\right]&=K_{n 2}\left(V_{G S 2}-V_{T}\right)^{2} \\ K_{n 1}\left[2(2-1) V_{x}-V_{x}^{2}\right]&=2 K_{n 1}\left(2-V_{x}-1\right)^{2} \\ 2 V_{x}-V_{x}^{2} &=2\left(1+V_{x}^{2}-2 V_{x}\right) \\ &=2 V_{x}^{2}-4 V_{x}+2\\ 3V_{x}^{2}-6 V_{x}+2 &=0 \\ V_{x}^{2}-2 V_{x}+\frac{2}{3} &=0 \\ V_{x} &=1 \pm \sqrt{\frac{4-\frac{8}{3}}{4}}=1 \pm \sqrt{\frac{1}{3}} V \\ V_{GS2}&=\left(2-V_{x}\right) \geq V_{T}\\ \Rightarrow \quad \left(1-V_{x}\right) &\geq0\\ \text{So, valid value,} \quad V_{x}&=1-\sqrt{\frac{1}{3}}=0.4226 \mathrm{V} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 44 A solar cell of area  1.0 [latex]cm^{2}[/latex] , operating at 1.0 sun intensity, has a short circuit current of
20 mA, and an open circuit voltage of 0.65 V. Assuming room temperature operation and
thermal equivalent voltage of 26mV, the open circuit voltage (in volts, correct to two
decimal places) at 0.2 sun intensity is _______.
solution: For solar cell, [latex] \begin{aligned} V_{\mathrm{OC}} &=V_{T} \ln \left(\frac{I_{S C}}{I_{O}}\right) \\ V_{\mathrm{OC} 2}-V_{\mathrm{OC} 1} &=V_{T} \ln \left(\frac{I_{S C 2}}{I_{S C}}\right)=V_{T} \ln \left(\frac{0.20}{1.0}\right) \\ V_{\mathrm{OC} 2} &=V_{\mathrm{OC} 1}-0.026 \mathrm{ln}(5) \\ &=0.65-0.041845=0.608 \mathrm{V} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 45 A junction is made between [latex] p^{-} Si [/latex] with doping density [latex] N_{A1} = 10^{15} cm^{-3}[/latex] and pSi with doping density[latex] N_{A2} = 10^{17} cm^{-3} [/latex]. Given: Boltzmann constant [latex]k = 1.38 \times  10^{-23} JK^{-1} [/latex], electronic charge [latex] q = 1.6 \times  10^{-19} C [/latex]. Assume 100% acceptor ionization. At room temperature (T = 300K), the magnitude of the built-in potential (in volts, correct to
two decimal places) across this junction will be _________________.
solution: Built-in potential, [latex] \begin{aligned} V_{b i} &=\frac{k T}{q} \ln \left(\frac{N_{A 2}}{N_{A 1}}\right) \\ &=\frac{1.38 \times 3}{1.6 \times 100} \ln (100) \mathrm{V}=0.1192 \mathrm{V} \\ & \simeq 0.12 \mathrm{V} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 46 In the circuit shown below, a positive edge-triggered D Flip-Flop is used for sampling input
data [latex] D_{in} [/latex] using clock CK. The XOR gate outputs 3.3 volts for logic HIGH and 0 volts for
logic LOW levels. The data bit and clock periods are equal and the value of[latex] \Delta T/T_{CK} = 0.15 [/latex],
where the parameters [latex]\Delta T [/latex] and [latex] T_{CK} [/latex] are shown in the figure. Assume that the Flip-Flop and the XOR gate are ideal. If the probability of input data bit [latex] ( D_{in}) [/latex] transition in each clock period is 0.3, the average value (in volts, accurate to two decimal places) of the voltage at node X , is _______.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} V_{X(\mathrm{avg})} &=\left[0.3 \times 3.3\left(1-\frac{\Delta T}{T_{C K}}\right)\right]+[0.7 \times 0] \mathrm{V} \\ &=0.3 \times 3.3 \times(1-0.15) \mathrm{V} \\ &=0.3 \times 3.3 \times 0.85 \mathrm{V}=0.8415 \mathrm{V} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 47 The logic gates shown in the digital circuit below use strong pull-down nMOS transistors for
LOW logic level at the outputs. When the pull-downs are off, high-value resistors set the
output logic levels to HIGH (i.e. the pull-ups are weak). Note that some nodes are
intentionally shorted to implement "wired logic". Such shorted nodes will be HIGH only if
the outputs of all the gates whose outputs are shorted are HIGH. The number of distinct values of [latex]X_{3}X_{2}X_{1}X_{0}[/latex] (out of the 16 possible values) that give Y = 1 is _______.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} A&=\left(X_{1} \oplus X_{2}\right) \bar{X}_{3} \\ B&=\left[\left(X_{1} \oplus X_{2}\right) \bar{X}_{3} X_{0}\right] \cdot \bar{X}_{0}=0\\ Y&=B+X_{3}=0+X_{3}=X_{3} \end{aligned}[/latex] Out of 16 possible combinations of [latex]x_{3} x_{2} x_{1} x_{0} x_{3} ,[/latex] will be high for 8 combinations. So, Y will be high for 8 combinations.

question:
Question 48 The cutoff frequency of [latex] TE_{01} [/latex] mode of an air filled rectangular waveguide having inner
dimensions [latex]a cm \times b cm ( a \gt b)[/latex] is twice that of the dominant [latex] TE_{10}[/latex] mode. When the
waveguide is operated at a frequency which is 25% higher than the cutoff frequency of the
dominant mode, the guide wavelength is found to be 4 cm. The value of b (in cm, correct to
two decimal places) is _______.
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} f_{c(01)}=2 f_{c(10)}=\frac{2 c}{2 a}=\frac{c}{a} \\ \frac{c}{2 b}=\frac{c}{a} \Rightarrow a=2 b \Rightarrow b=\frac{a}{2} \end{array}[/latex] Operating frequency, [latex] f=1.25 f_{c(10)}[/latex] [latex] f_{c(10)}\lt 1.25 f_{c(10)} \lt \left[f_{c(01)}=2 f_{c(10)}\right][/latex] So, for the given frequency, the waveguide will work in [latex]\mathrm{TE}_{10}[/latex] mode. [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { So, } \lambda_{g} &=\frac{\lambda_{0}}{\sqrt{1-\left(\frac{f_{c(10)}}{f}\right)^{2}}} \\ &=\frac{c / f}{\sqrt{1-\left(\frac{1}{1.25}\right)^{2}}}=\frac{c / f}{0.6} \\ \frac{c}{(1.25) f_{c(10)}(0.6)} &=\lambda_{g}=4 \mathrm{cm} \\ \frac{c}{f_{c(10)}} &=3 \times 10^{-2}=2 a \\ a &=1.5 \mathrm{cm} \\ b &=\frac{a}{2}=0.75 \mathrm{cm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 49 A uniform plane wave traveling in free space and having the electric field [latex]\vec{E}=(\sqrt{2}\hat{a}_{x}-\hat{a}_{z})cos[6\sqrt{3}\pi \times 10^{8}t-2\pi (x+\sqrt{2}z)]V/m[/latex] is incident on a dielectric medium (relative permittivity [latex]\gt[/latex]1, relative permeability = 1) as shown in the figure and there is no reflected wave. The relative permittivity (correct to two decimal places) of the dielectric medium is___________.
solution: The wave has [latex]E_{i}[/latex] direction and propagation  direction both in same plane (ZX). The wave is plane of incidence (P) polarized. [latex] \begin{aligned} \beta_{x} &=1, \quad \beta_{2}=\sqrt{2} \\ \tan \theta_{i} &=\frac{\beta_{z}}{\beta_{x}}=\sqrt{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] No reflection in P polarized wave under Brewster's angle of incidence. [latex] \begin{aligned} \theta_{i} &=\theta_{B} \\ \tan \theta_{B} &=\sqrt{2}=\sqrt{\epsilon_{r}} \\ \epsilon_{r} &=2 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 50 The position of a particle y(t) is described by the differential equation: [latex]\frac{d^{2}y}{dt^{2}}=-\frac{dy}{dt}-\frac{5y}{4}[/latex] The initial conditions are y(0) = 1 and [latex]\left.\begin{matrix} \frac{dy}{dt} \end{matrix}\right|_{t=0}=0[/latex]. The position (accurate to two decimal places) of the particle at [latex]t = \pi[/latex] is _______.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{d^{2}}{d t^{2}}+\frac{dy}{dt}+\frac{5Y}{4}&=0\\ y(0)&=1 \\ y^{\prime}(0)&=0 \end{aligned}[/latex] By applying Laplace transform, [latex] \begin{aligned} s^{2} Y(s)-s(1)+s Y(s)-1+\frac{5}{4} Y(s)=0 & \\ Y(s)=\frac{s+1}{s^{2}+s+\frac{5}{4}}=\frac{s+1}{\left(s+\frac{1}{2}\right)^{2}+1} \\ =\frac{\left(s+\frac{1}{2}\right)}{\left(s+\frac{1}{2}\right)^{2}+1}+\frac{\frac{1}{2}}{\left(s+\frac{1}{2}\right)^{2}+1} \end{aligned}[/latex] By taking inverse Laplace transform. [latex] \begin{aligned} y(t)&=e^{-t / 2}\left[\cos (t)+\frac{1}{2} \sin (t)\right] ; t>0\\ \text{At }t=\pi &\\ y(t=\pi) &=e^{-\pi / 2}[(-1)+(0)] \\ &=-e^{-\pi / 2}=-0.2078 \simeq-0.21 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 51 The contour C given below is on the complex plane z=x+jy , where [latex] j=\sqrt{-1} [/latex]. The value of the integral [latex]\frac{1}{\pi j}\oint_{C}^{}\frac{dz}{z^{2}-1}[/latex] is _______.
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} \frac{1}{\pi \dot{i}} \oint \frac{d z}{z^{2}-1}=2\left[\frac{1}{2 \pi i} \oint_{C_{1}} \frac{d z}{(z+1)(z-1)}+\frac{1}{2 \pi i} \oint_{C_{2}} \frac{d z}{(z+1)(z-1)}\right] \\ =2\left[-\left.\left(\frac{1}{z-1}\right)\right|_{z=-1}+\left.\left(\frac{1}{z+1}\right)\right|_{z=1}\right] \\ =2\left[-\left(-\frac{1}{2}\right)+\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)\right]=2 \end{array}[/latex]

question:
Question 52 Let [latex]r=x^{2}+y-z[/latex] and [latex]z^{3}-xy+yz+y^{3}=1[/latex]. Assume that x and y are independent
variables. At [latex](x, y, z) = (2, -1,1)[/latex], the value (correct to two decimal places) of [latex]\frac{\partial r}{\partial x}[/latex] is _________ .
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} r &=x^{2}+y-z &\ldots(i)\\ z^{3}-x y+y z+y^{3} &=1 &\ldots(ii)\\ \frac{\partial r}{\partial x} &=2 x-\frac{\partial z}{\partial x} &\ldots(iii)\\ 3 z^{2} \frac{\partial z}{\partial x}-y+y \frac{\partial z}{\partial x} &=0 \\ \frac{\partial z}{\partial x} &=\frac{y}{3 z^{2}+y} \end{aligned}[/latex] By substituting [latex]\frac{\partial z}{\partial x}[/latex] in equation (iii), we get, [latex] \begin{aligned} &=2 x-\frac{y}{3 z^{2}+y} \\ \operatorname{At}(2 .-1.1),& \\ \frac{\partial r}{\partial x}&=2(2)-\frac{(-1)}{3(1)^{2}+(-1)} \\ &=4+\frac{1}{2}=4.50 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 53 Consider the network shown below with [latex] R_{1} = 1\Omega , R_{2} = 2\Omega  \; and \; R_{3} = 3\Omega  [/latex]. The network is connected to a constant voltage source of 11V. The magnitude of the current (in amperes, accurate to two decimal places) through the source is _______.
solution: As the network is symmetric, [latex]V_{A}= V_{B} and V_{C}= V_{D}[/latex] So current throught [latex]R_{2}[/latex] resistor is zero and [latex]V_{A}=V_{B}[/latex] and [latex]V_{C}[/latex]=[latex]V_{D}[/latex],electrically the circuit can reduced as, Total resistance, [latex] \begin{aligned} R_{T} &=2\left(R_{1} \| R_{1}\right)+\left(R_{1}\left\|R_{1}\right\| R_{3} \| R_{3}\right) \\ &=R_{1}+\left(\frac{R_{1}}{2} \| \frac{R_{3}}{2}\right) \end{aligned}[/latex] Given that, [latex]R_{1}=1 \Omega[/latex] and [latex]R_{3}=3 \Omega [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \text{So,}\qquad R_{T} &=1+\left(\frac{1}{2} \| \frac{3}{2}\right) \Omega=1+\frac{3 / 2}{4}=\frac{11}{8} \Omega \\ I &=\frac{11 \mathrm{V}}{R_{T}}=\frac{11}{(11 / 8)}=8 \mathrm{A} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 54 A band limited low-pass signal x(t) of bandwidth 5 kHz is sampled at a sampling rate [latex] f_{s} [/latex].
The signal x(t) is reconstructed using the reconstruction filter H(f) whose magnitude
response is shown below: The minimum sampling rate [latex] f_{s} [/latex] (in kHz) for perfect reconstruction of x(t) is _______.
solution:
Let us assume an arbitrary spectrum for x(t) as 
shown below: The spectrum of the sampled signal can be given 
as, For proper reconstruction of the signal, [latex]
\begin{aligned}
 f_{s}-5 & \geq 8 \\
 f_{s} &\geq 8+5=13 \mathrm{kHz} \\
\text { So. } \quad  f_{s(\mathrm{min})} &=13 \mathrm{kHz}
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 55 Let [latex]X[k]=k+1[/latex], [latex]0\leq k \leq 7[/latex] be 8-point DFT of a sequence [latex]x[n][/latex], where [latex]  X[k]=  \sum_{n=0}^{N-1} x[n]e^{-\frac{j2nk\pi }{N}}[/latex]. The value (correct to two decimal places) of [latex]\sum_{n=0}^{3}x[2n][/latex]  is _______.
